What is better for a horror aficionado than one HELLRAISER movie? Two HELLRAISER movies in the same package, for a surprisingly reasonable price. Never mind special features, DVD extras, and all that jazz; what we've got here is a (pardon the pun) "stripped to the bone" double feature which showcases the only two really good films in this entire franchise.

HELLRAISER is the story of Frank Cotton (Sean Chapman), a degenerate hedonist who, having run out of illicit pleasures, purchases the so-called "Lament Configuration," a beautiful but spooky-looking puzzle box said to open the gates of "heaven or hell" when correctly solved. Frank is so debauched, so jaded and burned out, that he no longer cares which, provided he can go "beyond the limits" of pleasure or pain as he knows them. Unfortunately for Frank, he gets precisely what he wants at the hands, or rather the hooks, of four demonic beings called the Cenobites, only to discover, too late, that he doesn't want it. Exit Frank to the sound of screams. Enter Frank's nice-guy brother Larry (Andrew Robinson) and his unhappy, scheming second wife Julia (Claire Higgins), who move into the old family homestead Frank occupied before he solved the box. Unbenknownst to Larry, Julia had an affair with Frank long ago, and still lusts after his memory, so when Larry cuts himself moving in, and the blood re-animates the scattered remains of Frank beneath the floorboards, Julia readily agrees to supply him (Frank) with more blood so he can complete his regeneration and run off with her. To do this, of course, she'll have to murder a number of people, but she's so completely under Frank's spell she doesn't much care. The fly in the ointment is Larry's plucky daughter Kirsty (Ashley Lawrence), who loves her dad and distrusts Julia. When Kirsty discovers Frank is still alive (albeit without his skin), she opens the box and strikes a bargain to deliver him back to the Cenobites, who, let's face it, aren't the most trustworthy folks to deal with. Bloody hell ensues, culminating in a climax as gory as it is satisfying.

Writer-director Clive Barker views HELLRAISER (based on his novella "The Hellbound Heart") as a love story first, and he's right, but the real love in the movie is not between Frank and Julia, but between Kirsty and her well-meaning dad, who is the complete innocent caught between horrible millstones. As for the Cenobites, forget it. A more awe-inspiring and mesmerizing gang of villains you will not find anywhere, though I must say Frank Cotton remains one of the most disgustingly evil characters in the history of cinema -- that rare baddie who has absolutely no redeeming qualities at all, yet remains oddly charismatic. And the soundtrack, by Christopher Young, is one of the best film scores I've ever heard. While not a perfect movie, HELLRAISER is a damned good one, a classic to stand the test of time.

The sequel, HELLBOUND is not anywhere near as good taken on the whole, but at its best it approaches and even occasionally exceeds its progenitor. It begins with Ashley incarcerated in a mental institution since, of course, nobody buys her story about cursed puzzle boxes and leather-clad demons. Unfortunately for her, the hospital is run by the sinister Dr. Chennard (Kenneth Cranham), who is obsessed with the legend of the Cenobites and uses his influence to obtain the bloody mattress upon which Julia met her fate in the first film. Through methods too disgusting to recount here, he resurrects Julia and uses a traumatized mental patient who is a savant with puzzles (Imogen Boorman) to "safely" open the Lament Configuration, whereupon he begins a tour of Hell with the ever-scheming Julia as his guide. At the same time, Ashley is contacted by the "ghost" of her father, who pleads with her to rescue him from that same Hell. Ever the devoted daughter, Ashley, uniting with a sympathetic doctor (William Hope, of "Aliens" fame), does just exactly that, and confronts her old foes, the Cenobites, on their own turf. As usual, there is a tangle of different motives at work, lubricated by blood and gore, as well as an unwelcome appearance by the loathsome (yet charismatic) Frank Cotton. More bloody hell ensues, spilling out into the "real world" before the "puzzle" is finally solved.

I saw HELLBOUND in the theater when it was released, and the scanty audience was extremely confused by the melange of tones in the storytelling. Working from a story by Clive Barker, director Tony Randel labors mightily to recapture the gory yet hi-concept feeling of the first film, and there are moments when he succeeds brilliantly, aided, once again, by a towering score from Christopher Young, and some terrific production design. Unfortunately, the film is hamstrung by the absence of Andrew Robinson, who was low-balled by the studio and refused to reprise his role as Larry Cotton, thus gutting the most poignant part of Barker's original script (which I have read). In addition, the latter portion of the film degenerates into a somewhat incomprehensible mess, at times slipping into a pastiche of slasher horror movies as Chennard takes over from the Cenobites as the movie's principal villain. All in all, HELLBOUND is a glorious and gory mess of a movie, far superior as individual parts rather than a whole, and for all of its flaws, it is infinitely better than any of the innumerable and often unwatchable sequels that followed.

So, my advice is to buy this double feature. Light some candles. Get on your knees. Open the box. And go to hell.

#2: I don't know if these are copy-on-demand or not but mine don't really work. The discs are Region "1/A" which should work in the US. Hellraiser did not work on either my region-free player or my US player. Nor my PS4 or laptop or desktop. It does work in my PS3 though. Really?? Hellraiser 2 will not play on anything. I assume I received a bad copy but as usual, at this price point, it's not really practical to return it. I will be the only one losing money.

Clive Barker's Hellraiser is landmark horror.  It stands up well 28 years later.  Where some directors shy away from the lust of their characters, Barker rides the razor's edge of eroticism & pain.  Some of the scenes make you wince, yet they turn you on.  Add to this mix, a grand music score by Christopher Young -- his breakthrough film.
I bought the whole series it is good.
Great movie from my childhood.
Hands down this has to be one of my favorite horror flicks of all time.

This is a great value for fans who just want an inexpensive way to have both the first two Hellraiser movies in one package.  I thought the transfers looked fine (depending on how fine your examination is... but it's better than DVD quality I think)... sound was crisp as well.

The one thing that sucks about this package though, is NO CLOSED CAPTIONING!!  We like having the subtitles on just to make sure we catch every word of the dialog (particularly in sections where it gets quiet or something), but neither of these discs has any subtitles at all.  BOO!!!

As for my opinion of these movies - really I can be happy only watching the second one since it includes much of the good parts of the first movie as an intro anyway.  The second movie has all the cool stuff with the psych ward and much more of the otherworldly stuff with Pinhead and the gang (room of chains in particular), all the Escher-inspired labyrinth scenes, the fun part of seeing Frank in Hell, and all the gruesome "GET 'EM OFF MEEEEE" stuff with the bloody mattress.

I really like Hellraiser and the sequal Hellbound: Hellraiser II.  I've always enjoyed horror movies, this is a must own for any horror movie fan.  Subsequent Hellraiser movies seem to fall short as the plot lines significantly deviate from these two.  The first film has a more simple plot line than the sequel, both films are extremely violent and full of murder.

The first film takes place primarily in a single location, which is Kirsty Cotton's new family home.  Her uncle Frank gets resurrected from hell and terrorizes Kirsty and her father Larry.  The second film takes place in a mental hospital where Kirsty has been placed in.  The evil doctor who runs the hospital resurrects Julia (Larry's wife) who terrorizes everyone in the mental hospital, including Kirsty.

I give this film a thumb up and five stars for its originality and captivating visuals.  Very well done by creator/director Clive Barker and director Tony Randel.

These films are classics to me but they made no effort whatsoever to clean up these aging prints. Hi Def only accentuates the many pits, dings, n general flaws on the film print they used to make this set. But ten bucks for 2 movies I hadn't owned isn't a bad deal. I hope someday somebody will finally treat these classics with enough respect to give them the proper hi Def treatment they deserve.

As a child of the 80's I grew up in the golden age of horror. My parents had Dracula, The Blob, and Frankenstein. I had Jason, Freddy and Michael. I love horror films, but even as a kid, the first two "Hellraiser" movies felt different from the other horror films. Maybe it's the tone, maybe it's the Hell imagery, or the excessive, realistic gore? But when you watch these two films, they aren't tapping into the same place as when you watch Jason hacking through campers or Freddy stalking the hapless teens of Springwood.

"Hellraiser" is a tightly written horror movie based on Clive Barker's "Hellbound Heart". Seeking the ultimate pleasure, a man named Frank buys a small puzzle box, and upon solving it, he opens a gateway to Hell. Tortured by demonic monsters known as cinabites. Frank's brother moves into Frank's old house, and when the brother cuts his hand spilling blood on the floor, he unwittingly begins Frank's resurrection.

"Hellbound: Hellraiser II" picks up right where the first film left off. Kirsty is the sole survivor of the attack by Frank and the cenobites. Of course no one believes her story and she's committed to a mental hospital. Unfortunately, Kirsty's doctor knows she is telling the truth, and he hopes to re-open the. Passage to Hell by having a young girl solve the puzzle box.

Both films are brutally bloody, and after they are over you'll feel the need to shower. "Hellraiser" is a much better film than it's sequel, better pacing and a tighter story keep the action moving. "Hellbound" features long scenes of people running down hallways and it feels like so much filler.

If you are a fan of 80's horror, then these films are must own. If nothing else you'll be shocked at the level of gore presented in these mainstream films, and Pinhead has become a horror icon.

The movies look great.

Just a quick 'buyer beware':  this two-film set has the worst image quality I've ever personally seen on a blu-ray transfer. I've tossed this in the trash and reclaimed my DVD set, which has much better image quality. Shame on you, Image, these transfers are simply awful.  And unfortunately the worst transfer of the two is the original film, one of the best horror films ever made.
Time for someone (Scream Factory are you listening?) to step up and give us a high quality blu-ray transfer of at least the original film, which in my book is a classic.  The one-star review is thus for this specific release (Image Entertainment, Sept. 2013), not for the amazing 'Hellraiser.'

This review is for the Blu-ray set.  When I first saw these two movies in the cinema years agoI was quite blown away.  I decided to replace my VHS copies (finally) and saw this double BD set.  I was very happy to see that Echo Bridge had not gotten their hands on these two films.  The video transfer is excellent, though the audio is a bit lacking in dynamic range.  There are no extras, either.  Still, all in all, a great buy.

I received my DVD's in beautifully clean, pristine condition - not a mark or scratch on the discs, not even a fingerprint and the case was in equally as great of condition.  I was extremely happy with this purchase for the price.

Thank goodness Image Entertainment has this instead of Echo Bridge. The transfers, even though old, are very sharp and clear and anamorphic 1.85/78.1. I wish Image had parts 3, 4 and 5 also as the Echo Bridge versions are unwatchable It's such a waste.

With me, the first one truly ranks as one of the creepiest films ever produced. This is a movie in the genre of "The Exorcist" in that it stands alone in the way it being a different way to present terror. This isn't to say the two are anything alike, only they presented horror in new ways. The whole movie seems hell-bent on making you as uncomfortable as it can and with me, at least, succeeds. The character of Frank is as evil a person as has ever been depicted in a film, but his "reward" at the end is so horrific that it says with me to this day. The second movie is a bit of a let-down but still far more effective than any of the slapped together, poor attempts to stretch the franchise basing it on the Cenobite commonly referred to as "Pin Head". But this package is a good buy as you get enough of the story to be satisfied with without having to get involved with any of the other movies of the franchise.
The beginning of the end of mankind.  The constant struggle for redemption is epic.  In the end we all will be in hell.  Awesome start to a great series.

These are truly genuine horror films that have raised the horrific bar in the genre. The second is a continuation of the first with some closure to it that doesn't obviously lead to a third in the franchise. Makes the double feature containing both appropriate. Blu-ray transfers are very good, both picture and audio, but the disks are bare-bones with English audio (no other dubbed languages), no subtitles, and very little for extras beyond trailers. Got the 4th and 5th Hellraiser movies as part of a bundle and they're nowhere near the first two in suspense or horror. Don't know at this point if I'm going to pursue the 3rd one or not and may just stop with the first two as apparently a number of others have done.
